name: it
description:
Many hyperscript commands return a value which is stored in the local variable scope as result or it.  Subsequent commands will often overwrite this value, so you'll need to store it in your own variable before it gets erased.
For possessive expressions, its will also work, as in its property instead of it.property.
typical_value_or_referent: The result of the previous command or implicit object in current context
scope_implications: This uses the fetch command to load data from a server, an as expression to parse JSON, then puts the result into a local variable called "people"
usage_context:
fetch /my-server/people as an Object
    put it into people
nt :x then put it into the next
t(:x) then put it into the next
by 2 then put it into the next
, 2)) then put it into the next
x, 2) then put it into the next

'Clicked!' in it
	put it in me"

rray, ul)
	for item in array
		-
re me then log it">Click Me To M
ample then put it into my innerH
syntax_examples:
fetch /my-server/people as an Object
    put it into people

def formatPizzaToppings(toppings)
  make an Intl.ListFormat from "en", { type: "conjunction" }
    called listFmt

  for part in listFmt.formatToParts(toppings)
    if the part's type is "element"
      make a <span.topping/>
      put the part's value into its textContent
      append it to #toppings
    else
      append the part's value to #toppings
    end
  end

pick items from start to 4 from arr
--      it = [10, 11, 12, 13]
pick items from 2 to end from arr
--      it = [12, 13, 14, 15]
pick items from start to end from arr
--      it = [10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15]

set str to "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog."
pick match of "the (\w+)" from str
log it[0] -- "the lazy"
log it[1] -- "lazy"
pick match of "the (\w+)" | i from str
log it[0] -- "The quick"
log it[1] -- "quick"

set str to "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog."
pick match of "the (\w+)" | i from str
repeat for match in result index i
  log `${i}:`
  log it[0] -- "The quick"
  log it[1] -- "quick"
end

-- the basic for loop
  repeat for p in <p/>
    add .example to p
  end

  -- syntactic sugar for the above
  for p in <p/>
    add .example to p
  end

  -- iterating over an array but without an explicit variable
  -- instead the keyword it is used
  repeat in <p/>
    add .example to it
  end

  -- iterate while a condition is true
  repeat while #div matches .active
    put "Still waiting." into #div.innerHTML
    wait 1s
    put "Still waiting.." into #div.innerHTML
    wait 1s
    put "Still waiting..." into #div.innerHTML
  end

  -- iterate until a condition is true
  repeat until #div does not match .active
    put "Still waiting." into #div.innerHTML
    wait 1s
    put "Still waiting.." into #div.innerHTML
    wait 1s
    put "Still waiting..." into #div.innerHTML
  end

  -- iterate until an event 'stop' occurs
  repeat until event stop
    put "Still waiting." into #div.innerHTML
    wait 1s
    put "Still waiting.." into #div.innerHTML
    wait 1s
    put "Still waiting..." into #div.innerHTML
  end

  -- iterate five times
  repeat 5 times
    put "Fun " before end of #div.innerHTML
  end

  -- iterate forever
  repeat forever
    toggle .throb on #div
    wait 1s
  end

<!--
  here we spin off the fetch and put asynchronously and immediately
  put a value into the button
-->
<button
  _="on click async do
                      fetch /example
                      put it into my.innerHTML
                    end
                    put 'Fetching It!' into my innerHTML"
>
  Fetch it!
</button>

<button _="on click increment :x then put it into the next <output/>">
  call increment :x
</button>
<output></output>

<button _="on click increment(:x) then put it into the next <output/>">
  increment(:x)
</button>
<output></output>

<button _="on click increment :x by 2 then put it into the next <output/>">
  increment :x by 2
</button>
<output></output>

  increment(:x) by 2
</button>
<output></output>

<button _="on click call(increment(:x, 2)) then put it into the next <output/>">
  call(increment(:x,2))
</button>
<output></output>

<button _="on click increment(:x, 2) then put it into the next <output/>">
  increment(:x, 2)
</button>
<output></output>

eventsource demo from http://server/demo

    on message as string
        put it into #div
    end

    on open
        log "connection opened."
    end

    on close
        log "connection closed."
    end

    on error
        log "handle error here..."
    end

end

-- define the SSE EventSource
eventsource UpdateServer from http://server/updates
    on message
        log it
    end
end

-- elsewhere in your code, listen for the "cancelGoAway" message, then disconnect
on cancelGoAway from UpdateServer
    log "received cancel message from server"
    call UpdateServer.close()
end

eventsource DynamicServer
    on message as json
        log it
    end
end

-- somewhere else in your code
DynamicServer.open("test.com/test1.sse") -- creates a new connection to this URL

DynamicServer.open("test.com/test2.sse") -- automatically closes the first connection
DynamicServer.close()

DynamicServer.open("test.com/test3.sse") -- reconnects to a different endpoint.

name: me
description:
Most hyperscript features run within the context of an HTML element.  For example, <div _="on click ..."> is an event handler that runs in the context of the <div> that contains it.  Within these scripts, you can use the me expression as a link back to their associated HTML element.
For possessive expressions, my will also work, as in my property instead of me.property.
typical_value_or_referent: The current element that owns the hyperscript code
scope_implications:
This uses the put command to update the contents of the associated element.
This uses a possessive expression and an attribute reference to display a custom message.
This demonstrates the possessive expression along with the increment command to makes a simple click counter.
usage_context:
oo', 'bar') on me">
  Set foo to
iv _="on click measure me then l

n click remove me
"
>
  Click to
syntax_examples:
<button data-script="on click put 'I have been clicked' into me">
    click me
    </button>

Click to highlight paragraphs

</button>

  Set foo to bar on me
</button>

           js(me, text)
               if ('clipboard' in window.navigator) {
               	 return navigator.clipboard.writeText(text)
               	   .then(() => 'Copied')
               	   .catch(() => me.parentElement.remove(me))
               }
           end
           put message in my.innerHTML "

Click to get rid of me

<script type="text/hyperscript">
  behavior Removable
    on click
      remove me
    end
  end
</script>
Click to get rid of me
Click the button to close me

<script type="text/hyperscript">
  behavior Removable(removeButton)
    on click from removeButton
        remove me
    end
  end
</script>

<script type="text/hyperscript">
  behavior Removable(removeButton)
    init
      if no removeButton set the removeButton to me
    end

    on click from removeButton
      remove me
    end
  end
</script>

<script type="text/hyperscript">
  worker Miner("/scripts/mine-crypto.js")
  	js
  		var miner = new CryptoMiner();
  		return { miner }
  	end

  	def startMining() miner.start() end
  	def stopMining() miner.stop() end
  end
</script>

<label>
  <input
    type="checkbox"
    _="on change
                            if me.checked Miner.startMining()
                            else Miner.stopMining()"
  />
  Disable ads <small>and enable cryptocurrency mining</small>
</label>

def loadExample ()
    add @disabled to me
    fetch /example
    put the result after me
  finally
    remove @disabled from me
  end

name: you
description:
The you reference is available within the tell command as a reference to current node being acted upon.
Most hyperscript features run within the context of an HTML element.  For example, <div _="on click ..."> is an event handler that runs in the context of the <div> that contains it.  Within these scripts, you can use the me expression as a link back to their associated HTML element.
If it makes the code more readable in English, yourself can be used as an alias.
For possessive expressions, your will also work, as in my property instead of me.property.
scope_implications:
This uses the append command to update the contents of every

tag. This uses the remove command to remove all elements with the disabled=true property This uses a possessive expression to decrement the value of every element targeted
syntax_examples:
tell <p/>
    append "some value" to you
end

  finally
